awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: RUI: Diversification Dynamics of Multitrophic Interactions in Tropical Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
How is biodiversity generated and maintained? Much evidence suggests that parasites play an important role in both the origin and the maintenance of biological diversity. This project focuses on one of the most diverse groups of organisms on the planet: herbivorous insects, their parasites, and their microbes. The project targets three economically important groups of organisms: plants in the pumpkin/cucumber family, true fruit flies that attack these plants, and parasitic wasps that kill the flies. These wasps belong to a highly diverse and little studied group of species. Each wasp species can kill only one fly species; wasps attacking the "wrong" species of fly die. These bi-directional lethal interactions may be mediated by microbes (in wasps, flies, or both), by traits of flies' immune systems, or both. This project is designed to uncover the mechanisms (evolutionary, ecological, and immunological) affecting interactions that may help explain the diversity of life. Many species of true fruit flies are major agricultural pests; this project will greatly increase knowledge about factors contributing to their susceptibility to parasitoids. 

The project tests hypotheses that predict that: 1) defenses of parasites and their hosts affect diversification rates; 2) mechanisms of virulence differ among lineages, and 3) selection arising from predator-prey interactions can affect rates of species-formation. To discover and identify mechanisms of diversification, participants will generate and analyze molecular 1) high-resolution genetic data, multiple nuclear loci, and mtCOI haplotypes to delineate species, and resolve deeper phylogenetic relationships; 2) microsatellites and ddRAD-seq markers to discover and quantify fine-scale genetic diversity within and among populations; 3) phylogenies and field experiments to test hypotheses about mechanisms generating and controlling diversity on ancient, recent, and contemporary timescales. Undergraduate students from all participating colleges and universities will participate in the research.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Thanks to the award from the Dimensions of Biodiversity program, we were able to collect specimens in eight sites in five countries: Costa Rica (Monteverde), Ecuador (lowland and highland sites in the Napo province), French Guiana, Peru (the Iquitos region), and Trinidad. These sites and collections were especially important because they allowed us to replicate methods used at other sites, and resample regions for which previous collections were compromised due to changes in the host-countries' permit processes. Our expeditions resulted in the collection of 24,952 plant parts (hosts of flies) and 5640 insect specimens.

Population/Community Structure Dimension: These collections will allow us to construct snapshots of the species composition and host-parasitoid interactions within communities at each site. Those snapshots, along with analyses of thousands of single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) throughout the distribution of six widespread fly species, will allow us to reconstruct the history of community assemblies.

We use a "barcode" gene --the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit I gene (mtCOI)-- to identify flies.  Identification of parasitoid wasps relies both on mtCOI and at least two nuclear markers. We now have 15,441 fly barcodes and 2616 wasp barcodes representing specimens collected in sixteen sites in eleven countries. Our records will allow us to reconstruct the histories of host-parasitoid interacctons.

Functional Dimension: We now have collections representing both specimens reared to adulthood (which represent surviving flies and wasps) and specimens killed at the puparial stage (which represent the fly-host and may contain wasp DNA). By comparing host-parasitoid patterns revealed by adults with patterns revealed in puparia (pre-adult stage), we can detect patterns of bidirectional lethality: adult wasps show us which wasps successfully kill their prey; puparia that contain DNA of wasps that never emerged as adults show us that immature flies can defend themselves against wasps.

At one site, we preserved puparia in RNAlater so that we could compare the transcriptomes of parasite-free flies with flies attacked by parastoid wasps. Those data may help us see how flies manage to kill their parasitoid predators (parasitic wasps). At most sites we also preserved adult female wasps in RNAlater to allow a collaborator to assay those samples to detect RNA associated with bacteria or viruses that might help wasps overcome the flies' defenses.

Phylogenetic Dimension: Using Anchored Hybrid Enrichment (AHE) methods, we have long sequences of genes that have proved useful in phylogenetic analysis of flies. Those AHE sequences have enhanced our confidence in the structure of the Blepharoneura phylogeny.

Broader Impacts 

Seventeen U.S. undergraduates (9 female, 7 male; 2 African American; 3 Hispanic) were involved in this research both in the field and in the laboratory. The project helped train three graduate students (at the University of Iowa and the University of Georgia) and three postdoctoral researchers. The project also provided training to two Ecuadorian undergraduates and two Peruvian students.

The organisms we study are related to economically important species. The insects we study are in the same family as serious pests (e.g., apple maggot, and Mediterranean fruit fly) and attack plants in an economically important family-- the squash and cucumber family. Our findings could help inform development of biological control programs for pests. 


Last Modified: 11/16/2021
Modified by: Martha A Condon
